title: Intimacy Communication
description: Explore how you communicate about physical closeness

questions.text: I can talk to my partner about what feels good physically.

therapeutic.rationale: Communicating about what feels good improves physical connection over time. Without this communication, partners guessâ€”sometimes correctly, sometimes not.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't talk about this, explore what makes it difficult. Embarrassment? Fear of hurting feelings? Building safety for this conversation helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to communicate about what feels good creates learning and improvement.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How easy is it to tell your partner what feels good? What would make it easier?

questions.text: I sense receptiveness when I share something about our physical connection.

therapeutic.rationale: Receptivity to feedback about physical connection encourages more sharing. Defensiveness or hurt closes down communication.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't experience receptivity, explore what happens when they share. The listening partner may not realize how they respond.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual receptivity to physical feedback creates ongoing improvement.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner respond when you share something about your physical connection?

questions.text: We can navigate conversations about physical needs without it becoming tense.

therapeutic.rationale: Conversations about physical needs can easily become charged. When they stay calm, couples can address real issues rather than getting lost in defensiveness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If these conversations become tense, explore what triggers the tension. Feeling criticized? Fear of inadequacy? Understanding triggers helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ability to discuss needs calmly creates productive conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes conversations about physical needs feel safe or tense?

questions.text: I feel understood when I try to express something about intimacy.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling understood when discussing intimacy encourages continued openness. Feeling misunderstood leads to giving up on communication.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel understood, explore what's getting lost. Sometimes it's about how things are said; sometimes about how they're heard.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual understanding in intimacy conversations builds confidence to keep sharing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you feel understood when you try to express something about intimacy?

questions.text: Talking about physical closeness brings us closer, not further apart.

therapeutic.rationale: Conversations about intimacy should ideally strengthen connection. When they create distance, something in how the conversation happens needs attention.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If talking creates distance for one partner, explore what happens in these conversations that pushes them away.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared experience of connection through intimacy conversations is a strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do conversations about physical closeness affect your connection?
